question: Sure you were. What do you say we have a look at your catch? Me, I woulda thrown 'em back. Vamanos. Fuera. Hagan una lina! What do you get, Nick? Hundred bucks a head? Two hundred? I hope you saved it all for your lawyer, pal, 'cause you're gonna need --
answer: We'll take it from here.

question: Who the hell are you?
answer: INS Division 6.

question: Division 6? I never heard of Division 6.
answer: Really? What're we thinking, Dee?

question: !Oye! Que pasa, coma estas? Hey! No se preocupe, abuela. Bienvenida a los Estados Unidos. A donde vas? San Antonio? Buscando trabajo, no? Buena suerta. Es un placer verle aqui. Que dices si te rompo la cara? No hablas ni una palabra del Espanol, verdad, amigo? We got a winner. Los restos estan libres a irse. Largense!
answer: Sir!

question: Tomen el camion, y vayeuse.
answer: Sir, you can't just --

question: Don't "Sir" me! You have no idea who you're dealing with! We're gonna have a little chat with our friend here. You boys can hit the road ... and keep on protecting us from dangerous aliens.
answer: You ever heard of Division 6?

question: I think you jumped off the bus in the wrong part of town, amigo. In fact, I'll bet dollars to pesos that you're not -- -- from anywhere near here. Mikey?! When did they let you out of jail? Political refugee. Right.
answer: You know how many treaty articles you've just violated?

question: One, my ass. Try seven.
answer: From unauthorized immigration to failure to properly inoculate prior to landing.

question: Okay, that's enough. Hand me your head and put up your arms. Ah, shit. Dee! Shoot him! Dee, for Christ's --
answer: Th -- th -- th --

question: "That."
answer: That wasn't -- wasn't -- wasn't --

question: Human, I know. Oops. Got some entrails on you. Okay, everybody, situation's under control, calm down. If you'll just give me your attention for a moment I'll tell you what happened. This is called a "neuralyzer." A gift from some friends from out of town. The red eye here isolates and measures the electronic impulses in your brain. More specifically, the ones for memory. Gimme a splay burn on the perimeter, please; holes at 40, 60, and 80. Exactly the right question. And the answer lies right -- here. Pay attention. Really? I'm just a figment of your imagination. God, we're a gullible breed. I mean it, fellas, you are lucky to be alive after a blast like that.
answer: What -- blast?

question: Underground gas vein, genius. You guys need to exercise more caution before discharging your firearms. Especially you.
answer: I'm sorry. About...back there.

question: Happens.
answer: Didn't used to. The spirit's willing, Kay, but the rest of me... They're beautiful, aren't they?

question: What?
answer: The stars. We never just -- look. Anymore. I'll tell ya, Kay. I will miss the chase.

question: Grand Central Station off to your left, folks... Dammit, man, you're making me sweat up my gear! Yo, man, your luck just ran out. And when he gets here, I'll kick his ass too. What the... Wassup? Stop! What are you?!
answer: Perpetrator then blinked two sets of eyelids. You mean blinked with both eyes?

question: No, sir. He blinked once with one set, then again with another completely different set.
answer: Was that before or after he drew the weapon which you claim evaporated into a million pieces?

question: After, sir.
answer: And why do you suppose none of the other officers saw either of these two events?

question: 'Cause some of the other officers are a little soggy in the midsection. And they couldn't keep up, sir. What do you mean? I am half the man you are. My problem is you being all up in my damn face all the time.
answer: Sergeant. I want to talk to you outside. Now.

question: You have really pretty eyes.
answer: Dr. Weaver, from the coroner's office? Working on the John Doe?

question: Yes. That's right.
answer: Would you look right here, please.

question: Some night, huh?
answer: Oh, yeah, some night.

question: They were gills. Not eyelids.
answer: Who are you?

question: Did he say anything to you?
answer: Yeah, sure. He said the world was coming to an end.

question: Did he say when?
answer: You're kidding, right?

question: Would you recognize his weapon if you saw it again?
answer: Absolutely.

question: Let's take a ride.
answer: Wait a minute. I got a ton of paperwork.

question: You ran that guy down on foot? That's tough. That's double tough.
answer: So who you with? You got the plain clothes, the government-issued wheels. Secret Service? CIA? Yeah, well, whoever it is, you're short on funding.

question: Nothing is what it seems, kid.
answer: Oh, yeah, my bad '86 Ford LTD. That's a luxury ride. C'mon, who ya with?

question: I'm part of a secret organization that monitors and polices alien activity on earth.
answer: This is where we're going? Jack Jeebs? Guy buys from chain snatchers. Doesn't even sell guns.

question: Really?
answer: All right, you think it's worth shaking him up, fine. I'll do my thing. Then I want some answers.

question: Officer Edwards. Oh, hey, geez, how'd these get here? I thought I turned 'em in to the proper authorities.
answer: Way I hear it, Jeebs, you into something a little hotter than some stolen Rolexes.

question: Sure -- I'm a big crack dealer now. I just work here because I love the hours.
answer: I'm talking about guns, Jeebs. High-tech stuff.

question: C'mon, Edwards, whatcha see is what I got.
answer: Why don't you show him the imports, Jeebs.

question: H-hiya Kay, how are you?
answer: The imports, Jeebs. Now.

question: You know I got outta that business a long time ago, Kay.
answer: Why do you lie to me? I hate it when you lie.

question: Whoa, whoa, Kay, hold on a minute here...
answer: I'm going to count to three.

question: I'm going to count to three.
answer: He'll do it, Jeebs.

question: One.
answer: I've seen him do it.

question: Two.
answer: Talk to me, Jeebs, he's crazy when he's like this.

question: Three.
answer: Put down the gun and put your hands on the counter!

question: I warned him.
answer: Drop the weapon!

question: You warned him.
answer: You are under arrest. You have the right to remain silent.

question: You sold a carbonizer with implosion capacity to an unlicensed cephlapoid.
answer: He looked all right to me.

question: A carbonizer is an assassin's weapon, Jeebs. Who was the target?
answer: I don't know.

question: Jeebs!
answer: I don't know!

question: This is all confiscated. All of it. I want you on the next transport off this rock. Or I'll shoot you where it doesn't grow back.
answer: Yeah. I'll be by tomorrow for those Rolexes. The eyelids, fine ... and the jumping thing ... and the gun ... okay, but the head?

question: Searching for a handle on the moment here? A place to file all this.
answer: See a head doesn't do that, it doesn't just grow back. What's going on?

question: Can't help you, kid. Only comfort I can offer is that tomorrow, you won't remember a thing.
answer: Oh, no. This I'm gonna remember for a long, long time.

question: Ever see one of these? -- and the wife says yeah, Harry, I know, but this one's eating my popcorn!
answer: Huh?

question: Whoops. Gotta run. Thanks for the egg rolls.
answer: Where am I?

question: See what I mean about tequila? You're a bright young man, James. Just lay off the sauce. I'll see you tomorrow, nine a.m. sharp.
answer: Coffee. Please.

question: What on earth was it?!
answer: Sugar.

question: I've never seen sugar do that.
answer: Give me sugar. In water. More.

question: Edgar, your skin! It's -- it's -- just hanging off your bones!
answer: That better?

question: Maybe, I'm not sure, see, I got this card --
answer: You're late. Sit down. My name is Zed. You're all here because you're the best of the best. Marines, Navy SEALS, Army Rangers...NYPD. And we're looking for one of you. Just one. What will follow is a series of simple tests designed to quantify motor skills, hand-eye coordination, concentration, stamina -- I see we have a question.

question: Why, uh -- I'm sorry, it's just no one really asked this, but -- why, exactly, are we doing this?
answer: Son? What's so funny, Edwards?

question: I -- I don't know, sir. This guy. "Best of the best of the best of the best of the --" It just struck me as -- Humorous. Sir.
answer: Okay. Let's get going.

question: Anyone, uh...any of you guys know what we're doing here? Well, yeah, I know, but...
answer: The hell happened?

question: Hesitated, sir.
answer: May I ask why you felt little Tiffany deserved to die?

question: She was the only one who actually seemed dangerous. At the time.
answer: And how did you come to that conclusion?

question: Hook-head guy. You explain to me how he can think with a hook for a head. Answer; it's not his head. His head is that butt-ugly bean-bag thing over there. 'Cause if you look at the snarling beast-guy, he's not snarling, he's sneezing -- he's got tissues in his hand. No threat there, and anyhow, the girl's books were way too advanced for an eight-year-old's. And besides, from where I'm looking, she was the only one who appeared to have a motive. And I don't appreciate your jumping down my throat about it. Or, uh -- do I owe her an apology?
answer: He's got a real problem with authority.

question: Everybody thought the agency was a joke. Except the aliens. They made contact on March 2nd, 1961, outside New York City. There were nine of us that night. Seven agents. An amateur astronomer. And one poor kid who got lost on the wrong back road.
answer: You brought the aliens flowers?

question: They were intergalactic refugees with a simple request. Let us use the earth as an apolitical zone for people without a planet. Ever see "Casablanca?" Same thing, no Nazis. We agreed. So we masked all evidence of their landing.
answer: The 1964 World's Fair was a coverup?

question: Why else would we hold it in Queens? Now left. More nonhumans arrive every year. They live among us, in secret.
answer: I see. Not to change the subject, but when was your last cat-scan?

question: Every six months; it's company policy.
answer: Well, thanks for the very amusing morning, but I'm hopin' you'll show me where I came in? 'Cause this is where I go out.

question: Yeah, sure, hang on, I wanna grab a coffee while we're right here. Don't tell me we've only got that powdered shit for cream again? Oh. For future reference, this is a better look for you. Any given time, around fifteen hundred landed aliens are on the planet, the majority right here in Manhattan. Most aliens are decent enough, just trying to make a living.
answer: Cab drivers?

question: Not as many as you'd think. Humans, for the most part, don't have a clue. Don't want one, either. They're happy. They think they've got a pretty good bead on things.
answer: Why the big secret? People are smart, they can handle it.

question: A person is smart. People are dumb. Everything they've ever "known" has been proven to be wrong. A thousand years ago everybody knew as a fact, that the earth was the center of the universe. Five hundred years ago, they knew it was flat. Fifteen minutes ago, you knew we humans were alone on it. Imagine what you'll know tomorrow.
answer: So what's the catch?

question: What you'll gain in perspective, you'll lose in ways you're too young to comprehend. You give up everything. Sever every human contact. No one will know you exist. Ever.
answer: Nobody?

question: You're not even allowed a favorite shirt. There. That's the speech I never heard. That's the choice I never got.
answer: Hold up. You track me down, put me through those stupid-ass tests, now you're trying to talk me out of it. I don't get it.

question: You got 'til sun-up.
answer: Is it worth it?

question: Takin' care of your pest problem.
answer: "Pest" problem? "Pest?"

question: Yeah. You got a hell of an infestation.
answer: You know, I have noticed an infestation here. Everywhere I look, in fact. Nothing but undeveloped, unevolved, barely conscious pond scum. So convinced of their own superiority as they scurry about their short, pointless lives.

question: Well -- yeah. Don't you want to get rid of 'em?
answer: In the worst way.

question: Let's go. He's a little...grouchy. A couple of hours wait after a 17-light-year flight would get on anybody's nerves.
answer: What branch of the government do we report to?

question: None. They started asking too many questions.
answer: So who pays for all this?

question: Oh, we hold a few patents on gadgets we confiscated from our out-of-state visitors. Velcro. Microwave Ovens. Liposuction. Here. A new recording device to replace CD's. So now I gotta buy the White Album again? This is amusing. Universal translator. We're not supposed to have it. I'll tell you why. Human thought is so primitive it's considered an infectious disease. Makes you proud, doesn't it?
answer: What's this?

question: Don't touch that! Caused the '77 New York blackout. Practical joke by the Great Attractor. He thought it was funny as hell.
answer: Sorry!

question: Observation, the heart of our little endeavor. This map shows the location of every registered alien on earth at any given time. Some of them we keep under constant surveillance. Everyone on these screens is an alien. In public -- normal. In private -- you'll get the idea. Meet the twins.
answer: I gotta be honest about something.

question: It makes no sense?
answer: It makes perfect sense. When I was a third grader in Philadelphia, they told me I was crazy 'cause I swore that our teacher was from, like, Venus or something.

question: What's your jacket size, Edwards?
answer: Uh -- forty regular.

question: Then let's put it on.
answer: Put what on?

question: The last suit you'll ever wear. From now on, you'll dress only in attire specially sanctioned by MIB Special Services.
answer: KAY is at a computer terminal. On screen are Edwards's birth certificate, driver's license, social security card, library card, everything. ZED'S VOICE continues:

question: You'll conform to the identity we give you, eat where we tell you, live where we tell you, get approval for any expenditure over a hundred dollars. You will have no identifying marks of any kind. You will not stand out in any way.
answer: One by one, KAY deletes Edwards's identity cards.

question: Your entire image is carefully crafted to leave no lasting memory whatsoever with anyone you encounter. You're a rumor, recognizable only as deja vu and dismissed just as quickly. You don't exist; you were never even born. Anonymity is your name. Silence your native tongue. You are no longer part of "the system." We're above the system. Over it. Beyond it. We're "them." We're "they." We are the Men in Black.
answer: Looking slick and handsome in his extremely sharp suit, JAMES D EDWARDS III -- or, rather, JAY -- steps into the doorway from the locker room. He reaches into his pocket, takes out the sunglasses, and looks at KAY.

question: Yo, wussup with Zed? "Go get em, tiger. We're not hosting an intergalactic kegger..."
answer: Zed was saving the world before you were born, son. Show some respect.

question: We got the use of unlimited technology from the entire universe and we cruise around in this?
answer: Seat belt.

question: You know, ya'll gotta learn how to talk to people. You could be a little kinder and gentler.
answer: Buckle up, please.

question: Now did that hurt?
answer: Makin' fun of my ride... Jay. The button?

question: Yeah?
answer: Never push the button, Jay. License and registration, please. Other license and registration, please. Your resident card has you restricted to the five boroughs only. Where do you think you're going?

question: What new arrivals? This have anything to do with the crasher from last night?
answer: Can you guys do this later?! Oh -- oh -- oh -- man.

question: Congratulations! It's a lizard.
answer: Hey, you know, it is sorta --

question: Anything about that seem unusual to you?
answer: Pick.

question: What kind of "new arrival" would scare Redgick so bad that he'd risk a warp jump with a newborn? Let's check the hot sheets.
answer: These are the hot sheets?

question: Best damn investigative reporting on the planet. But hey, go ahead, read the New York Times if you want. They get lucky sometimes.
answer: You're actually looking for tips in a supermarket tabloid?

question: Not looking for. Found. Not so fast. Walk up slow.
answer: Why?

question: Part of the routine. Makes it look like we're sizing up the situation. Gives her time to get the wrong impression. Puts some fear into her. Makes things go smoother.
answer: Can I help you gentlemen?

question: How do you do, ma'am, I'm Special Agent Manheim, this is Agent Black, FBI. Had a few questions about your visitor.
answer: Are you here to make fun of me too?

question: No ma'am. We at the FBI don't have a sense of humor that we're aware of. Mind if we come in?
answer: Sure. Lemonade? And they said to me, "If he was murdered, how could he walk back in the house?" And I must admit, I was a little stumped by that one. But I know Edgar. And that wasn't him. It was more like something else that was wearing him. Like a suit. An Edgar suit.

question: Sorry?
answer: Go on.

question: Anyway, when I came to, he was gone.
answer: Did he say anything?

question: Yes! He asked for water. Sugar water, if I remember.
answer: Sugar water.

question: Sugar water.
answer: Did you taste her lemonade?

question: Ray Bans. Okay, Beatrice. There was no alien, and the flash of light you saw in the sky wasn't a UFO. Swamp gas from a weather balloon was trapped in a thermal pocket and refracted the light from Venus --
answer: Whoa! That thing erases her memory, and you give her a new one?

question: Standard issue neuralyzer.
answer: And that's the best you can come up with?

question: On a more personal note, Beatrice, Edgar ran off with on old girlfriend. Go stay at your mother's for a few days and get over it. Decide you're better off.
answer: Yeah, and you're better off 'cause he never appreciated you anyway. In fact, you kicked him out, and now that he's gone, you ought to buy some new clothes, maybe hire a decorator or something... Hey. Kay...when am I gonna get one of those memory things?

question: When you're ready. Please -- not green. Do you know what alien life form leaves a green spectral trail?
answer: Wait -- don't tell me -- that was the question on Final Jeopardy last night.

question: Zed, we have a bug.
answer: I'm gonna jump way past you and just guess that this is bad. Right?

question: Bugs thrive on carnage, Tiger. They consume, infest and destroy. They live off the death and decay of other species.
answer: So basically you have a racial problem with all insect-based life forms?

question: Listen, kid -- imagine a giant cockroach five times smarter than Albert Einstein, four times stronger than an ox, nine times meaner than hell, strutting his stuff around Manhattan Island in his brand new Edgar suit. Does that sound like fun?
answer: What do we do?

question: Sorry I'm late. The cab drivers on this planet are terrible.
answer: Your majesty, you are in grave danger.

question: Yeah, and they overcharge you every time.
answer: Sir, a bug landed here. We must get you off the planet.

question: A bug? He must know why I'm here.
answer: We think he does. Is that what I think it is?

question: No, just some diamonds for your children. Do we have time to eat?
answer: Sure. I ordered you some pirogi. To the continued reign of the Arquillian Empire.

question: Where do you want contestant number three?
answer: By the wall, I guess. What's with the cat?

question: Oh, the cat. There's a problem with the cat. Sign here.
answer: What's the problem with the cat?

question: Your problem.
answer: Are you having a bad day, baby? Cheer up. His is worse. Okey-dokey. Shall we? Oh, my God. ...approximately 112 degrees at time of autopsy, indicating, quite impossibly, a post-mortem increase in body temperature. Examiner attempted to verify result rectally, only to find subject was, uh, without rectum. Which can only be described as...well...as really...

question: Are you having a bad day, baby? Cheer up. His is worse. Okey-dokey. Shall we? Oh, my God. ...approximately 112 degrees at time of autopsy, indicating, quite impossibly, a post-mortem increase in body temperature. Examiner attempted to verify result rectally, only to find subject was, uh, without rectum. Which can only be described as...well...as really...
answer: Weird? Dr. Leo Menville, Department of Public Health. This is Dr. White.

question: Yeah, well whoever you are, I'm afraid I'm going to need to see some ID. You boys must not have much of a home life.
answer: We watch the morgues very carefully. You've got something unusual?

question: I'd say so -- triple homicide. The first corpse was perfectly normal, except that he was broken in half, but when I opened up the other two -- well, look. There's a skeletal structure at work here unlike anything I've ever seen.
answer: I'll have a look at this one. Dr. White, why don't you and Dr. Weaver check out the other body?

question: This way, Doctor. This one's even stranger. I did a full laparotomy. I started with the lesser curvature of the stomach -- though, if you want, we could begin at the gastro-esophageal junction.
answer: I think, uh, we should start at the same place you did.

question: All right.
answer: Your cat?

question: Guess it is now. Came in with the bodies. Okay. Dive right in. God knows he won't mind. You have very pretty eyes.
answer: Thank-you, but is this really the time to uh -- you know, come on to me?

question: Hey, just walking the dog. Feel that? Where the piloric junction would be?
answer: Oh, yes. Exactly.

question: Now push that aside. Notice anything strange? Stomach? Liver? Lungs?
answer: Nope. All fine.

question: Doctor, they're all missing.
answer: Well, of course they are. What I'm pointing out is that there are no pieces of them left. So they're intact, wherever they are. That we can be sure of.

question: Have we met before? I have the strangest feeling of deja vu.
answer: You know, I was just going to ask you the same thing.

question: Okay. You wanna know what I really think? But don't tell that guy. He looks like he's already under enough stress. This body is not really a body, but it's actually some sort of transport unit for something else altogether. The question is By the way, stop me if I'm freaking you out.
answer: No, no...not at all.

question: You know what I like to do sometimes? When it's really late?
answer: No... Excuse me.

question: No... Excuse me.
answer: What do you think?

question: Very interesting. Got a real Queen of the Undead thing goin' on.
answer: Of the body.

question: Great body.
answer: The dead body?

question: Not a clue.
answer: All right. Keep her occupied. Try not to sound too dumb.

question: Look at this.
answer: What is that?

question: Far -- freaking -- out.
answer: It's all right -- What are you trying to say? Struggle?

question: War?
answer: Bed? Belt? Orion's Belt? "To prevent war, the galaxy is on Orion's Belt?" The hell does that mean? Hey! Kay! I mean, Dr., uh, whatever, come here!

question: "Doctor Whatever"? You're not with the Department of Public Health, are you?
answer: He's dead.

question: Sure thing, sweetheart. Here you go.
answer: Stop that --

question: Typical day, too much caffeine, get a life.
answer: -- that thing probably gives you brain cancer!

question: Never hurt her before.
answer: "Never hurt her before"?! How many times have you done the flashy thing to this poor woman?!

question: Couple.
answer: Aren't you worried about, you know, long term damage?

question: Little bit.
answer: What the hell happened to make you such a callous son of a bitch?

question: I took this job.
answer: Hey, you never flashed me with that thing, did you?

question: Nah.
answer: Hey, Kay, I really think I should be in charge of the flashy memory thing department.

question: Not while I'm around, Slim.
answer: Yeah, well you're a menace with that thing...

question: Doesn't anybody believe in sleep around here?
answer: The twins keep us on Alpha Centaurian time -- a 37-hour day. Give it a few months -- you'll get used to it. Or you'll have a psychotic episode. Here's Orion; the brightest grouping of stars in the northern sky... and here's Orion's belt --

question: That's what the little guy was talking about, "To prevent war, the galaxy's on Orion's belt..."
answer: There are no galaxies on Orion's belt. The belt is just these three stars; galaxies are huge, made up of billions of stars. You heard wrong.

question: What do they know that we don't know?
answer: Why do rats desert the ship? Go to Lem Sat IV. Put up a forty-field view of Manhattan. Four hundred. Four thousand. That's an Arquillian battle cruiser.

question: And we've got a dead Arquillian prince.
answer: Message coming in. Speak of the devil.

question: Who robs a jewelry store and leaves the jewels?
answer: Someone who's not looking for jewels.

question: This guy had a serious crush on his cat. Kay! GET DOWN! The bug in the Edgar suit! The ugly redneck from the picture! That's him!
answer: Damn it. We do not discharge our weapons in view of the public.

question: Can we drop the cover-up bullshit?! There's an Alien Battle Cruiser that's gonna blow-up the world if we don't...
answer: There's always an Alien Battle Cruiser...or a Korlian Death Ray, or...an intergalactic plague about to wipe out life on this planet, and the only thing that lets people get on with their hopeful little lives is that they don't know about it. Don't worry about the bug. He's not leaving town. We've got his ship. Zed, we're gonna need a containment crew down here at McDougal, south of Houston.

question: Containment may be a moot point, my friend. The exodus continues. It's like the party's over and the last one to leave gets stuck with the check. You sorry little ingrates!
answer: What about the Arquillians?

question: We've only translated a part of the message so far
answer: No, they don't want much, do they?

question: Oh, it gets better... They're holding us responsible. Another contestant has entered the ring.
answer: All right, kid. The Arquillians want the galaxy, whatever the hell that means. We need help. A professional. Someone with years of experience in intergalactic politics. I just hope the little prick hasn't skipped town.

question: You don't like it, you can kiss my furry little butt.
answer: You busy, Frank?

question: Sorry, Kay, I can't talk right now, my ride's leaving in --
answer: Call the pound. We got a stray.

question: Arquillians and bugs. What do you know?
answer: I know nothing.

question: Not a thing?
answer: Stop it. Okay, okay. Rosenberg wasn't some two-bit Arquillian. He was the guardian of a galaxy. They thought he would be safe here on earth.

question: And the bug had other plans.
answer: The galaxy is the best source for subatomic energy in the universe. If the bugs get their slimy claws on it, kiss the Arquillians goodbye.

question: Thank you for making sure the bell works. What's up, Farmer John?
answer: A man came in here earlier. A dead man.

question: And this means what to me?
answer: He was a very dear friend of mine. And I believe he had an animal with him. A gift I gave him, a pet cat that means worlds to me. I would like it back.

question: I'll need a picture ID, written proof of ownership of the cat, or notarized proof of kinship with -- -- the deceased.
answer: Don't -- do that.

question: Uh, hi.
answer: Hello.

question: I'm Sergeant Friday, from the Twenty-Sixth precinct. They brought a cat in here with a corpse the other day, might have said "Orion" on the cat's name tag?
answer: Yes. That's right.

question: Right, well, the cat is, uh -- the cat's a witness in a murder case and I'm going to need to take it with me.
answer: I don't know where the cat is at the moment.

question: You don't?
answer: No. Maybe you could take me with you instead.

question: Excuse me?
answer: I said, maybe you could take me with you instead.

question: Damn, you do start fast, don't you?
answer: I'd really like to go with you. Now.

question: And, uh, why exactly is that?
answer: I just do.

question: Don't shoot! Don't shoot!
answer: CHRIST, are you THICK!

question: How was I supposed to know!?!
answer: What did I have to do, SING it for you!?!

question: Maybe if you didn't come on like a drunken prom date!
answer: Oh, that's SO typical. Any time a woman shows the slightest hint of sexual independence, men just --

question: Everybody shut UP!
answer: Let her go, Shit Eater.

question: Listen, Monkey Boy, I may have to take that kind of talk in my end of the universe, but compared to you humans, I'm the top rung on the evolutionary ladder, so can it, all right?!
answer: You're breakin' my heart. Move six inches to your left and I'll solve all your problems.

question: That's better. Now put down your weapons. We're leaving. Have you ever pulled the wings off a fly? Would you care to see the fly get even?
answer: How far you think you'll get without your ship? If that's what you call that hunk of space crap we've got back at our office.

question: Put the weapons down!
answer: Never gonna happen, Insect.

question: Sucks, doesn't it?
answer: Pull up the locations of all land-based interstellar vehicles.

question: They're all gone. Frank the Pug took the last ship on the planet.
answer: Atlantic City?

question: Gone.
answer: That landfill on the Jersey Shore?

question: Whaddya say we bag us some bug?
answer: You're taking the tunnel?!

question: You know a better way to Queens?
answer: It's usually jammed?! I told you!

question: Jay. The button?
answer: Yeah?!

question: Push the button, Jay. And you may want to throw on a seat belt. Mind if I smoke?
answer: What?!?

question: In the car, I mean.
answer: I don't care!!

question: You don't get it. I've won. It's over.
answer: You are under arrest for violating number 4-1-53 of the Tycho accord. Please hand over any galaxy you might be carrying.

question: You milk-suckers! You don't matter! In a few seconds you won't even be matter!
answer: Move away from the vehicle and put your hands on your head.

question: That did not go at all like I had planned.
answer: This guy's really starting to bug me. Whatever happens, Jay, don't let him get on that ship.

question: Where are you going?
answer: Getting my gun back.

question: What!?
answer: Hey, Bug! I'm talking to you, Bug! You know how many of your kind I've swatted with a newspaper? You're just a smear on the sports page to me, you slimy, gut-sucking, intestinal parasite! Eat me!

question: You were saying?
answer: Getting eaten!? That was your plan!?

question: Worked.
answer: After I got the shit beat out of me!

question: And I almost got digested. It goes with the job.
answer: You coulda told me what you were doing.

question: Look, I know we got rules, but she did just bust the Bug for us. And so maybe you don't have to flashy thing her. Who's she gonna tell, anyway? She only hangs out with dead people.
answer: Not her. Me. They're beautiful, aren't they? The stars. I never just look anymore and they're beautiful.

question: Kay, you're scaring your partner.
answer: I haven't been training a partner -- I've been training a replacement.
